channel.title: actionSender 'Short-cuts'

item.title: actionSender 'Short-cuts'
item.dc:creator: @CodeForFame CodeForFame
item.description:
@CodeForFame wrote:

[quote=“Mental Piracy, post:7, topic:396934”][quote author=Kryptix link=topic=494090.msg3613365#msg3613365 date=1306783535]

Was this really worthy of its own topic, its not really hard to figure out. It also takes longer for the code to perform any action doing this.

Is any topic really worth its own topic? Who cares? If you don’t like the thread then move to another one.

And how do you know it takes longer? Do you have any benchmarks to back up what you’re saying?
[/quote]
No benchmarks necessary, its common sense if you know how java operates. Its also something that most sources already have in some form and is quite basic. Its just really nothing new.[/quote]

If you knew how Java worked, you’d realize that the method will probably be inlined.

Furthermore, you’re crying about performance when the performance decrease it might create is completely negligible compared to large amounts of other code in the rest of the application.

Not only that, but you’re trying to micro-manage everything, and encourage pre-mature optimizations; you need to settle the fuck down, and actually profile the code.

Read full topic

item.title: actionSender 'Short-cuts'
item.dc:creator: @Motaro Motaro
item.description:
@Motaro wrote:

[quote author=Mental Piracy link=topic=494090.msg3613977#msg3613977 date=1306819527]it calls sendMessage, and the sendMessage in the actionSender class, two methods. Compared to using actionSender.sendMessage() by itself, its faster trust me.

The previous way didn’t directly call actionSender though, it called the method getActionSender() as the actionSender declaration is private.

I misunderstood the topic as being more efficient code, not shorthand. Also jar size means next to nothing. The difference your changes made is minuscule. Also neatness is sometimes incorrect.

I just checked an old copy of RSCEmulation and getActionSender() was being sent 1,043 times making the JAR size roughly 25kB bigger. I know JAR size doesn’t really matter but the code reduction is big and at the end of the day it’s personal preference. I’d sooner not see getActionSender() 1,043 times throughout my source code and I’d also sooner not type it every-time I add a new line of code that uses it (which is actually very often).

You ran a test with two bits of code, each calling two methods for one action. Do it again testing just calling the direct method used, should save about a tenth of a second, where as yours saved a few hundredths of a second just based on structure.

But the previous way wasn’t like that… You’re flaming my way when the original way is slower. It seems like you’re just doing it because you want to argue.

The JAR size is smaller by roughly 25kB.
The code has been reduced dynamically affecting 1,043 lines of code.
The new way is quicker on the 10 tests I ran.
The only developer of the source code prefers it.

It seems to be a win-win situation to me.

I misunderstood the purpose of this post as i stated before. Changing method names doesnt warrant a topic in a development section as even the rs2 skiddies know how to do that. I thought it was a shortcut programmatically.

I posted this to create a debate more than anything as the forums are dull. If I can learn something from it then all the better. We’ve learnt that this way is marginally quicker and that your ‘common sense’ is wrong.

Tell me, what exactly does warrant a topic in this section? It has created a debate and we’ve both just learnt something. I think that’s far better than a RS2 kid accidentally posting a server advertisement in here personally.[/quote]

He means you’re calling your sendMessage() and actionSender.sendMessage(). You’re calling two sendMessage methods when you could just call one.

Read full topic

item.title: actionSender 'Short-cuts'
item.dc:creator: @The_Enforcer The Enforcer
item.description:
@The_Enforcer wrote:

An extremely stupid modification and an extremely stupid reason backing it up. If getActionSender().XXXX() appears n times in your code then it makes 2n method calls, same with your modification. How about you do getActionSender() on top of the method body and store it, then make calls on it directly, n + 1 calls. Don’t modify RSCD in a way that makes it even worse than it is. If you care about JAR size just use an obfuscator that attempts to use single character field/method names.

Read full topic

item.title: actionSender 'Short-cuts'
item.dc:creator: @Mental_Piracy Mental Piracy
item.description:
@Mental_Piracy wrote:

[quote=“Kryptix, post:4, topic:397123”][quote author=Mental Piracy link=topic=494090.msg3613951#msg3613951 date=1306818479]

public void sendMessage(String message) { actionSender.sendMessage(message); }
That calls two methods instead of one… thats the point im getting at[/quote]
It doesn’t though. actionSender isn’t a method.[/quote]
it calls sendMessage, and the sendMessage in the actionSender class, two methods. Compared to using actionSender.sendMessage() by itself, its faster trust me.

[quote author=Mental Piracy link=topic=494090.msg3613951#msg3613951 date=1306818479]All you did was change the name of getActionSender() to make it easier to write, but it improves nothing programmatically, is what i’m trying to say.

As I said in the original post it makes the code a lot nicer to look at when you don’t have to use getActionSender() in every line of code. It looks so much neater, makes it quicker to write code and reduced the JAR size considerably.[/quote]
I misunderstood the topic as being more efficient code, not shorthand. Also jar size means next to nothing. The difference your changes made is minuscule. Also neatness is sometimes incorrect.

[quote author=Mental Piracy link=topic=494090.msg3613951#msg3613951 date=1306818479]You basically ran benchmarks on the same thing twice.

No I didn’t. I ran a benchmark against the old way and the new way. You claimed that no benchmark is necessary as it’s common sense that the new way would be slower if you know how Java operates (which you were wrong about).[/quote]
You ran a test with two bits of code, each calling two methods for one action. Do it again testing just calling the direct method used, should save about a tenth of a second, where as yours saved a few hundredths of a second just based on structure.

[quote author=Mental Piracy link=topic=494090.msg3613951#msg3613951 date=1306818479]I just dont see why you would use this, instead of just calling the actual “actionSender.sendMessage()” since you had to import the class for your shortcuts anyways.

Code reduction as previously explained. And no, nothing new had to be imported.[/quote]
actionSender is already imported, so actionSender.sendMessage() would be faster efficiency wise.

I misunderstood the purpose of this post as i stated before. Changing method names doesnt warrant a topic in a development section as even the rs2 skiddies know how to do that. I thought it was a shortcut programmatically.

Read full topic

item.title: actionSender 'Short-cuts'
item.dc:creator: @xEnt xEnt
item.description:
@xEnt wrote:

as object is saying, better to have structure than a short name. Player should have player properties, not things like sendMessage, if anything rename getActionSender() to getAS() or something like that.

Read full topic

item.title: actionSender 'Short-cuts'
item.dc:creator: @Mental_Piracy Mental Piracy
item.description:
@Mental_Piracy wrote:

public void sendMessage(String message) { actionSender.sendMessage(message); }
That calls two methods instead of one… thats the point im getting at, if you want to really improve the code, eliminate the middle man per-say.

All you did was change the name of getActionSender() to make it easier to write, but it improves nothing programmatically, is what i’m trying to say.

You basically ran benchmarks on the same thing twice. I just dont see why you would use this, instead of just calling the actual “actionSender.sendMessage()” since you had to import the class for your shortcuts anyways.
Your shortcut takes just as long as the regular way its done, thus meaning they aren’t shortcuts…

Read full topic

item.title: actionSender 'Short-cuts'
item.dc:creator: @Mental_Piracy Mental Piracy
item.description:
@Mental_Piracy wrote:

[quote author=Mental Piracy link=topic=494090.msg3613415#msg3613415 date=1306788327]No benchmarks necessary, its common sense if you know how java operates. Its also something that most sources already have in some form and is quite basic. Its just really nothing new.

The previous way called just as many methods as this way does… Please elaborate.[/quote]
Seriously… you are still calling the same methods as the original way, you are just making it call a method, that calls another method. Its like shipping, you can send something to a distribution center before shipping it to the destination(what you did). Or you can ship it directly to the final destination(way it was done originally), which do you think would be faster?

Read full topic

item.title: actionSender 'Short-cuts'
item.dc:creator: @Protosstribe object
item.description:
@Protosstribe wrote:

I don’t know why the size of the Jar file matters that much to you. Personally I wouldn’t care about it, but that’s just me.

Also, atleast I would prefer not to mix code that relates to the domain of a project with code that relates to network stuff, no matter the conveniency. In this case, the part I refer to domain code is Player and the ActionSender does send data over the network, so that’s the “network stuff” I am referring to. But of course, the network stuff were part of the domain even before you changed it, so I do not blame you. So it might aswell be “OK” for this project.

Read full topic

[quote=“Kryptix, post:1, topic:397123”][quote author=Mental Piracy link=topic=494090.msg3612884#msg3612884 date=1306731467]
Was this really worthy of its own topic, its not really hard to figure out. It also takes longer for the code to perform any action doing this.
[/quote]
Is any topic really worth its own topic? Who cares? If you don’t like the thread then move to another one.

And how do you know it takes longer? Do you have any benchmarks to back up what you’re saying?[/quote]

Method calls take time, but it’s usually negligible. And when it’s not, it gets dealt with behind the scenes.

Mental Piracy:

Was this really worthy of its own topic, its not really hard to figure out. It also takes longer for the code to perform any action doing this.

item.title: actionSender 'Short-cuts'
item.dc:creator: @Kryptix Kryptix
item.description:
@Kryptix wrote:

[code=java5]/**
actionSender “Short-Cuts”
*/

public void sendMessage(String message) {
actionSender.sendMessage(message);
}

public void sendGlobalMessage(long usernameHash, int rank, String message) {
actionSender.sendGlobalMessage(usernameHash, rank, message);
}

public void sendNotification(String notification) {
actionSender.sendNotification(notification);
}

public void sendAlert(String message, boolean big) {
actionSender.sendAlert(message, big);
}

public void sendQuestStarted(int questID) {
actionSender.sendQuestStarted(questID);
}

public void sendCompletedQuest(int questID) {
actionSender.sendQuestFinished(questID);
}

public void sendFriendUpdate(long usernameHash, byte online) {
actionSender.sendFriendUpdate(usernameHash, online);
}[/code]

Doing this for everything used publicly saved about 5-10kB on the JAR size. It makes the code smaller and nicer to write.

[font=courier]player.getActionSender().sendMessage()[/font] is now [font=courier]player.sendMessage()[/font] and so on.

Read full topic
